H0.text: Convection carries heat to the thermometer when one end of a metal rod is placed over a flame and the thermometer touches the opposite end of the rod during the investigation.

H1.text: Radiant energy warms the thermometer that is touching the opposite end of a metal rod placed over a flame during the investigation.

H2.text: Mechanical energy from the flame carries heat to the thermometer during an investigation in which one end of a metal rod is placed over a flame and the thermometer touches the opposite end of the rod.

H3.text: Heat from the flame is conducted through the metal rod to the thermometer when one end of the rod is placed over a flame and the thermometer touches the opposite end.

A4.text: Conduction is the main mode of heat transfer for solid materials because the strong inter-molecular forces allow the vibrations of particles to be easily transmitted, in comparison to liquids and gases.

A5.text: Heat transferred between the electric burner of a stove and the bottom of a pan is transferred by conduction.
